DOC.HEAD: Ambassador Davis Returns
Eds: Following also ran for AMs
DOC.TEXT: The following is a pool report filed by Steven Komarow of The Associated Press and Robert Kearns of Reuters.

U.S. Ambassador Arthur Davis returned to Panama after a seven-month absence Wednesday and declared that neighboring Latin American leaders would ``deep down'' be pleased that U.S. troops ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. But he warned that life in Panama would remain dangerous as Noriega loyalists retaliate. Davis left Panama the day after Noriega voided elections which most observers say he lost to opposition candidates now installed by the U.S. action. However, other Latin American countries have sharply criticized the United States and have refused to accept the new leadership in Panama so far. Davis said the position of those leaders was a reflection of their many years supporting non-interventionist treatment of their region. But he said privately they had to be pleased. ``I think that deep down that they're glad to get rid of this man,'' he told a heavily guarded press conference at Howard Air Base. Only a pool of reporters from Washington was allowed to attend. He expressed concern that Noriega supporters would seek revenge. ``I think that this is a very difficult time for security because of retaliation. There will be retaliation,'' Davis said. The returning ambassador said he was bringing an economic recovery plan for discussion with Panama's new leaders, but made no promise of U.S. aid except to point out that $700 million in assets would be returned as a result of President Bush's decision to lift economic sanctions.
